pros: Meaningful work, good colleagues, travel
cons: Lack of succession planning, limited growth opportunities

review_title: Meaningful public health work, but with its cons
pros: Steady stream of funding, budget to hire additional capacity where required. Meaningful work.
cons: Extremely HQ-centric. Weird rules which you can't really see a reason for. Several night calls due to the international nature of organization.

pros: Considerate employers for the most part. They also seemed somewhat organized
cons: No office in Ghana so salary payments were always complicated

pros: Department is solidly managed. Team members are trusted to do their jobs.
cons: Senior leadership doesn’t lead by example. They lack experience in the INGO field.

pros:
-Good health insurance
-Good flexibility in applying within
-Work from Home internationally flexibility
-Good Office Location
cons:
Do you want to be a victim of constant panic attacks due to extremely low morale and undervaluation by your employer? Then this is the place for you!

I know at least 5 people I intimately talked to who hated working here and felt "undervalued as a human being".  You are not even treated as a HUMAN BEING HERE. You are a bot who is working behind the camera. There was NO PERFORMANCE EVALUATION imposition that could help you feel recognized. My manager did not even know what I was working on, or even cared about the goal settings.

Its Opioid Prevention Program is one of its biggest teams, they do not care about their embedded staff. There are middle level staff members who care but are equally lost and in pressure because of the higher staff leaders. 

I had constant panic attacks by the end of the term and then when they said there would be a lay off due to incapacity, I felt relieved for my mental health than being upset.

pros: Good place for professional growth, especially in international setting
cons: As an international NGO, employees have to closely work with local partners

job_title: Program Officer in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, interesting work, lots of options
cons: Large organization, so has some downsides

pros: Flexible work environment Benefits are just a step above average
cons: Leadership is disconnected and out of touch Complete lack of development department- depend on funds from a handful of donors

review_title: Poor accountability, terrible leadership, and lack of upward mobility
pros:
Decent pay + benefits
Interesting work
Good place to start and leave
cons:
Leadership is protected from criticism 
Lack of accountability and leadership among senior staff
Feedback from employees is ignored or met with defensiveness
Poor onboarding systems within teams
Hard work is not rewarded, but personal friendships are
Lack of transparency in decision making
Responsibilities are often assigned beyond title and pay grade

review_title: Lost its way. Time for top level to step aside and bring in new, fresh leadership.
pros:
There are very smart, talented, and hard working staff. People really, really care about the work and are knowledgeable. 

Salaries and benefits are very generous.
cons: While the staff are pushing for change and wanting to be more inclusive, innovative and progressive, the organization is stuck with legacy, snoozy, executive leadership who are insular, not transparent, and lacking in any vision or ability to motivate and engage. They literally do not see it and think they are great. The only woman at the top is a bully, rude and condescending. She acts righteous and turns around and barks orders and runs the show. Sadly, she is untouchable as are the other leaders who all know each other from past work lives. Most of the executive team behave as if it is their way or the hi-way. This will drive away talented people who care and want to work for Vital.

review_title: Imperfect, but exciting place to work
job_title: Program Officer in New York, NY
pros: Generous benefits given the area of work; lots of opportunities to learn from colleagues, especially among program staff.
cons: Unclear pathways for advancement; leadership can be resistant to changes and take criticisms on equity personally

job_title: Senior Position in New York, NY
pros: A clear vision to solve public health problems
cons: None that I can think at the moment

pros: No micro-managing; everyone I've encountered is super friendly and willing to help. Great flexibility with work schedules.
cons: Has start up vibes, which isn't necessarily a bad thing but means things are always changing. Seems to make it harder to retain talent.

pros: great team of smart and pragmatic colleagues focused on global health issues
cons: needs more diversity among senior leadership, particularly wrt deep international health experience

review_title: A good start but no growth.
pros: Flexible environment and good health benefits.
cons: No clear structure on promotions and salary ranges. Mostly white staff gets promoted quickly and has salary at market level. It is a struggle to get an increase in salary or change in position.

job_title: Gerente de comunicaciones in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits and great team culture
cons: Promotions are slow and some times lack of comms between programs

review_title: Fun workplace great way to meet a lot of new people and make connections.
pros: They care about both their employees and the people (being a public health organization). They try to make sure that their employees have good experiences.
cons: Hard to get time off

pros:
Great organization, great mission
Wonderful colleagues
cons: Limited opportunities for growth. Lack of support as consultant

job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good work life balance and interesting work
cons: Not the best stability when I came to knowing what’s to come

pros: Incredibly talented knowledgeable teams doing important work, great benefits and they value work/life balance
cons: honestly cannot think of any cons!

job_title: Grants Officer in New York, NY
pros: Offer good benefits and days off
cons: Management only promotes and awards those employees that are favored. Hence, lack of career growth within the company, despite the promises during the interview process. Management also overworks and under compensates the employees. Different employees are held under different standards, and the administration does not even hide this fact.

pros: Decent pay for a non-profit (Bloomberg money) if you fit the profile and get hired by the right manager.
cons: Biased and unfair treatment based on daily or hourly emotional stability of manager — very unbalanced work culture between teams and individuals (some are allowed to work 2~ hours a day and travel extensively while others are monitored for 8 hours a day and are not allowed sick or vacation leave — for instance, I was fired for taking sick leave during the pandemic). There seems to be a lineage of original/founding managers that enable each other's toxic treatment of lower level staff. There also appears to be a clear advantage for white/non BIPOC employees regarding pay, upward mobility, and general treatment. Another con is lack of transparency regarding decisions and directions of programs and managers (a lot of questionable/poor judgement appears to drive the organization).

job_title: Grants Officer in New York, NY
pros: The company offers good benefits
cons: Too many negatives within the company. Management doesn't deliver on promises.

review_title: Great place to learn from sector experts
pros:
1) Good work-life balance
2) Good place to learn
cons: None that I can think of

pros: Great mission, doesn't take money from funders that create the problems they fund, wonderful culture and learning opportunities, appreciative of their staff.
cons: Nothing notable to mention. Best NGO that I've worked for.

job_title: Senior Project Coordinator in Blue Point, NY
pros: Access to technically sound leadership, impactful project, and career growth.
cons: Low salary, fast paced work environment

job_title: SVP-Service Delivery Executive in New York, NY
pros: Great and unique mission for public health
cons: Leadership egos and weak strategy

pros: competitive payment, flexible working time
cons: the team leader is not good

pros: Opportunity to work with high caliber public health professionals.
cons: Fast paced and high expectations.

pros: Great benefits (health, dental, vision, HSA)
cons: Remote working so disconnected from main office

review_title: Don’t bother if you don’t have personal connections.
pros: Good benefits and salary. A few skilled worker bees at the bottom ranks trying to survive and start their careers.
cons: Felt isolated as my incompetent boss ruled from afar. I complained to both local and global HR and found put that everyone at the top (including half of the Board) has a personal connection to the CEO.  It’s a no-win situation for talented people from the outside.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Amazing, hard-working colleagues that are passionate about the great work we're doing, incredibly good benefits, great salaries for a non-profit.
cons: People coming from a corporate environment might find the salaries lower than they're used to.

pros: Great teams, mission and quality of work with good work life balance
cons: Your asked to do a lot and if you come from government agencies or more traditional non-profit you may not be able to thrive right away due to the more start-up pace of work.

pros: Great benefits, work travel, great teams
cons: Very hectic and a lot of responsibility

pros: Manageable workload, some hardworking collegeues.
cons: Very cliquey, some employees with cliques get away with doing little other than sweet talk, other hard-working employees tend to be under the pump

job_title: Finance Officer in New York, NY
pros: Great work environment and staff!
